Dole, Helms, Dodd React To Panama Military Operation
DOC.TEXT: As first word circulated concerning the American military against Panama's Manuel Noriega, Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said early Wednesday he expects bipartisan support for President Bush's commitment of troops in Panama City. ``We need to see how it plays out,'' said Dole in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. ``I would guess there would be widespread bipartisan support for the president.'' Said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, ``The majority of the Senate will feel good by this turn of events. Certainly I feel a lot better.'' ``I called to tell the president, `my complements to the chef,''' he said in a telephone interview from his home in Raleigh, N.C. He said he had been briefed on the operation just prior to the White House news conference announcing the military mission. Immediate congressional reaction was limited because Congress is in recess and the White House announced its action at 1 a.m. Dole said Bush called him shortly before the early morning White House news conference announcing the military mission. He said the White House also was trying to reach Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who was in Mexico meeting with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, but Dole did not know if they'd gotten to him before the public announcment. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, also was briefed about the operation. ``We don't believe it would be appropriate to comment at this point,'' he said through his aide Jason Isaacson. Issacson said Dodd spoke to Secretary of State James Baker and ``is monitoring these events very closely. He is also making calls to other people in the region.'' Dodd has been generally supportive of President Bush actions concerning Noriega. Dole said he met with the elected Panamanian officials Dec. 10 and ``they were in effect pleading with us to do something'' about Noriega. Helms said he has confidence in the leaders of Panama sworn in Tuesday night under American auspices, and said he has no plans to bring up measures in the Senate calling for the abdication of the Canal Treaties negotiated by former President Jimmy Carter, even though he contines to oppose the treaties. ``I believe them to be sensible, rational people and some of my concern about the United States surrendering the canal has been diminished,'' said Helms.
